#part 1
In the hollow of the elder wood, where twilight’s hush is spun,  
A path winds slow beneath the boughs, where ancient stories run.  
The moss is thick upon the stones, the air is green and deep,  
And somewhere close, the forest’s heart begins to stir from sleep.  
A boy with lantern in his hand, his boots with morning dew,  
Steps softly past the sleeping ferns, alone but not untrue.  
The light he carries flickers gold, a trembling, hopeful spark,  
That pushes back the velvet dark and paints the world with mark.  
He’s searching for a whispered name, a promise left behind,  
A secret told in lullabies that only dreams can find.  
His mother’s voice, a distant bell, still echoes in his ear—  
“Go gently, child, and heed the signs; the forest listens here.”  
The owl blinks once from overhead, a sentinel in white,  
While foxes slip between the roots, their coats a ghostly sight.  
He follows where the river bends, its song a silver thread,  
And wonders if the tales are true, or only in his head.  
The trees lean close to watch him pass, their leaves a murmured prayer,  
And somewhere far beyond the path, the night wind stirs the air.  
A stone, a root, a sudden fall—he stumbles, gasps, and stands,  
With lantern nearly tumbled out and trembling in his hands.  
But onward still, the boy persists, his heart a steady drum,  
For something waits within the wood, and he must see it come.

#part 2
The forest deepens, shadows pool, and silence grows profound,  
Yet every step the boy now takes is careful, measured, sound.  
The lantern’s glow draws curious eyes from burrows, nests, and lairs,  
As creatures of the dusk arise to watch him unawares.  
A hare, its nose a quiver-twitch, appears along the trail,  
Its whiskers catching lantern light, its courage seeming frail.  
But as the boy regards the beast, he bows his head in peace,  
And so the hare, emboldened, stays—its watchful heart at ease.  
The path ahead grows tangled wild, with brambles clawing near,  
And yet the boy, with gentle hand, moves forward without fear.  
He hums a tune his mother sang, a melody of old,  
And finds the thorns draw back their teeth, the branches softly fold.  
He comes upon a willow tree, its limbs a curtain green,  
Beneath whose boughs an ancient stone, half-hidden, can be seen.  
Upon its face are runes engraved, their meaning lost to time,  
But as the lantern’s flame draws close, the carvings seem to shine.  
A voice, as soft as falling leaves, drifts out upon the air,  
And tells the boy of promises, of longing and despair.  
The tale is one of sorrowed love, of vows that could not keep,  
Of a maiden lost to shadow’s call, and a lover doomed to weep.  
It speaks of hope that flickers still, like lanterns in the night,  
Of those who brave the unknown woods in search of what is right.  
The boy, entranced, kneels by the stone, his fingers tracing lines,  
And wonders if his journey’s end is written in these signs.  
The willow sighs, a gentle breeze, its branches brushing low,  
And in that moment, time stands still—the world begins to slow.  
The boy recalls his mother’s words, her stories by the fire,  
And feels within his trembling chest a sudden, fierce desire.  
To find the truth, to heal the wound, to set old spirits free—  
He rises, lantern held aloft, and whispers, “Wait for me.”  
The forest, listening, seems to nod, its shadows drawing back,  
And so the boy resumes his quest, his courage holding fast.  
The moon climbs high, a silver coin, above the ancient trees,  
And somewhere in the hush of night, a secret stirs with ease.  
The path grows strange, the air turns cold, the river sings anew,  
And all the while, the boy walks on, his purpose clear and true.

#part 3
He finds at last a clearing wide, where moonlight floods the grass,  
And in its center, veiled in mist, a shadow seems to pass.  
It is the maiden of the tale, her eyes both sad and bright,  
A shimmer on the midnight air, a figure spun from light.  
She lifts her hand, and with a sigh, the world grows soft and thin,  
As if the veil that holds apart the now and then grows dim.  
The boy steps forward, lantern raised, his voice a trembling sound—  
“I come to bring the promise back, to heal the ancient wound.”  
The maiden smiles, a fleeting thing, both sorrowful and sweet,  
And as she speaks, the lantern flares, its radiance complete.  
She tells him all that once was lost can still be found anew,  
That hope is kindled, not in flame, but in the heart that’s true.  
She lays her hand upon the stone, the runes begin to glow,  
And in that light, the boy can see the way that he must go.  
He offers up his mother’s song, the melody of old,  
And finds the forest singing too, its story being told.  
The maiden’s sorrow lifts at last, her laughter fills the night,  
And all the wood is bathed in joy, awash with silver light.

#part 4
The forest breathes a gentle peace as dawn begins to break,  
And every leaf and blade of grass now glistens for his sake.  
The boy, exhausted but elate, walks slowly through the glen,  
His lantern’s glow a softer gold, its flame a trusted friend.  
Behind him trails the memory of stories come to rest,  
Of promises both lost and found, of quests that shaped his quest.  
He passes by the willow tree, its branches raised in cheer,  
The ancient stone now warm and bright, its carvings crystal clear.  
The hare he met along the path comes bounding to his side,  
And foxes watch from shadowed dens, their golden eyes grown wide.  
A chorus swells within the wood, the wind, the leaves, the stream,  
And in its heart, the boy can hear the echo of his dream.  
He knows the sorrow’s lifted now, the maiden’s spirit free,  
Her laughter woven in the dawn, a song of memory.  
He walks beneath the waking sky, the sun a crimson spark,  
And feels his mother’s arms around, a comfort in the dark.  
The journey home is gentle now, the world no longer strange,  
For in the hollow of the wood, he’s witnessed hope’s exchange.  
The lantern dims as daylight grows, its work at last complete,  
But in the boy, a brighter flame has kindled, fierce and sweet.  
He carries with him, deep inside, the wisdom of the trees,  
The courage found in whispered tales, the strength of mysteries.  
The forest bows to let him pass, its branches part in grace,  
And every step he takes is blessed by time and by this place.  
The river’s song is softer now, a lullaby for day,  
And all the creatures of the wood watch quietly his way.  
He leaves behind the tangled path, the brambles and the stone,  
Yet knows that in his heart of hearts, he’s never quite alone.

#part 5
The world beyond the forest edge is bright with morning sun,  
And in his chest, the boy can feel his journey’s just begun.  
He turns to see the woods behind, the shadows soft and kind,  
And knows the stories that he’s learned will never leave his mind.  
The lantern, now an ember faint, he carries just the same,  
A token of the night he passed, a memory and a flame.  
His mother waits with open arms, her smile a gentle shore,  
And in her eyes, he sees the love that guides him evermore.  
He whispers thanks to woods and stars, to secrets old and wise,  
And carries forth the forest’s heart beneath the open skies.  
For though the path may lead him far, through valleys yet unknown,  
He walks with hope, with story’s light, and never quite alone.

##prompt_id: 5, type: segmented, sample_id: 8

#part 1
In the village where the river bends like a lazy arm  
And the willows brush their fingers on the water’s gleam,  
There lived a woman named Mirelle, with eyes of storm,  
Whose laughter was a lantern through the night’s dark seam.  
She wore her hair in tangled braids, wild as the corn,  
And wandered fields at dawn where poppies dared to grow.  
She spoke in riddles to the wind, to beasts, to thorn,  
And left her footprints in the mud for all to know.  
The children watched her from the hedges, half in fear,  
Half in longing for the magic she could conjure up:  
A handful of crows from a hat, a fox drawn near,  
A cup filled with sunlight, poured into a silver cup.  
Once, they said, she’d danced with wolves beneath the moon—  
Her feet bare, her voice a song that tangled with the mist.  
Once, she’d vanished for a fortnight, returned too soon,  
Carrying a sprig of rosemary, her lips newly kissed.  
The elders frowned when she passed, clutching their beads,  
Muttering prayers to keep her shadow from their doors.  
But Mirelle only smiled, gathering her seeds,  
Planting secrets in the cracks of cottage floors.  
And so the seasons turned, and rumors grew like wheat,  
While Mirelle wandered, wind at her heels, dust on her feet.

#part 2
One summer, when the river shrank and fishbones glinted white,  
A sickness crept through the village with the dusk—  
First a cough, then a fever, then the shroud of endless night;  
It took the strong, the meek, the old, and left the air like musk.  
The healer’s herbs were powerless, the priest’s bells rang in vain,  
Families shuttered windows, drew their curtains tight.  
Children’s laughter vanished, replaced by whispered pain,  
And hope became a candle guttering against the blight.  
Yet through the empty lanes Mirelle walked unafraid,  
Her eyes reflecting sorrow, her hands cold as clay.  
She gathered water from the well, brought bread she’d made,  
And sang to restless infants at the break of day.  
Some said she was the cause, a witch who’d called the curse,  
Others begged her for a cure, their hearts torn and terse.  
She listened, silent as the moon, to every plea and wail,  
Then slipped away by starlight, following an unseen trail.  
One night, beneath the withered oak, she drew a circle wide,  
Scattered salt and rosemary, whispered to the sky.  
The air grew thick with memory, the wind itself replied,  
And shadows danced around her as she began to cry.  
She called upon old names—forgotten, fierce, and wild—  
The river’s ancient mother, the fox beneath the hill,  
The ghostly wolf who’d known her as a child,  
The poppy’s scarlet promise, the silence dark and still.  
Her voice wove through the branches, her tears upon the ground,  
Until the moonlight shivered, and the circle closed around.  
The villagers, restless in their beds, dreamed of running streams,  
Of laughter in the meadows, of fields washed clean.  
And when the dawn broke golden, the fever’s grip had flown—  
Leaving only dew, and the seeds Mirelle had sown.

#part 3
But peace is a brittle thing, and fear a stubborn weed—  
Whispers grew among the grateful, twisting what they’d seen.  
Some claimed Mirelle had bargained, paid a dreadful fee,  
That the sickness’ flight was bought with some unholy deed.  
They gathered in the market square, voices sharp as knives,  
Demanding answers, justice, someone’s sacrifice.  
Mirelle stood before them, her eyes calm and clear,  
Refusing both to tremble and to disappear.  
She spoke not of bargains, nor of debts or fate—  
Only of the river’s mercy, the fields’ quiet grace.  
But superstition’s hunger is never truly fed,  
And so they drove her from the village, hearts heavy with dread.  
She left at twilight, willow branches in her hair,  
Carrying nothing but her song and the cool, forgiving air.

#part 4
Beyond the village, Mirelle walked where wildflowers claim the stone,  
Where foxes dart like secrets through the tangled grass.  
She wandered forests thick with moss, fields overgrown,  
Her story trailing after her, a shadow she could not pass.  
The river’s bend grew distant, its waters out of reach,  
Yet still she heard its lullaby in every breeze.  
She spoke with ancient trees, learned what they could teach,  
And found a solace in the silence, a gentle, aching ease.  
Sometimes, travelers glimpsed her, a flash of russet braid,  
A laugh carried on the wind, a song half-remembered.  
They left offerings on stumps—honey, milk, a spade—  
Hoping she would bless them, or that their luck be tempered.  
Years unfurled their petals, slow and soft and green,  
And Mirelle’s legend blossomed, tangled with the wild.  
The children of the village, grown but still unclean  
With guilt, would wander out and call her name, beguiled  
By memories of healing, by the wonder she had spun.  
Some heard her laughter echo, others dreamed her face,  
Yet none could find her dwelling, nor undo what was done.  
The village healed and flourished, fields rich with grace,  
Yet always at the edge of things, a shadow lingered on—  
A sense of something lost, a gift that had withdrawn.  
And those who met misfortune, or fell to sorrow’s hand,  
Would sometimes find a sprig of rosemary left upon their land.

#part 5
In time, the village faded, the river changed its course,  
But stories lingered, whispered by the wind and rain.  
They spoke of Mirelle’s kindness, her laughter’s gentle force,  
Of the price of fear, and the wisdom found in pain.  
Children born of children heard her name as song—  
A woman wild and wondrous, who’d righted ancient wrongs.  
Her legend wove through meadow, through willow, through stone,  
A reminder not to cast out those who walk alone.  
And sometimes, in the hush before the dawn’s first light,  
A voice soft as river water slips into the night—  
A promise that the magic we banish or betray  
May yet return to heal us, in some far-off day.

##prompt_id: 6, type: segmented, sample_id: 1

#part 1

INT. DIMLY LIT LIVING ROOM – EVENING

A small, cluttered apartment. Books and papers are strewn across every surface. The only source of light is a flickering lamp in the corner. The air hums with tension.

At the center: OLIVIA (mid-30s, sharp-eyed, anxious) sits on a battered couch, a stack of letters in her lap. Across from her, MARCUS (early 40s, weary but resolute) stands by the window, peering through the blinds at the street below.

A clock ticks on the wall. Rain beats against the glass.

MARCUS (without turning)
How many times have you read them?

OLIVIA
(reading a letter, voice trembling)
I don’t know. I stopped counting after the fifth.

She sets the letter down, rubbing her temples.

MARCUS
(softly)
You shouldn’t keep torturing yourself.

OLIVIA
(tightly)
And you shouldn’t keep pretending this isn’t happening.

MARCUS
I’m not pretending.

He lets the blinds fall shut, turning to face her. His clothes are rumpled; his eyes, bloodshot.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
I’m trying to figure out what to do.

OLIVIA
There’s nothing to do. They know everything. They have everything.

She gestures at the letters, her hands shaking.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
They even know about the cottage, Marcus. The one place we thought was safe.

MARCUS
We don’t know that for sure.

OLIVIA
(reading)
“Your little haven in Glenbrook is charming. Perhaps we’ll visit, see what secrets you’ve hidden there.”

She crumples the page, tears pricking her eyes.

MARCUS
They’re bluffing.

OLIVIA
Are they? Because they knew about my mother’s ring. About the documents in the safe. About—

Her voice breaks. She swallows, regaining composure.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
If they’re bluffing, they’re very, very good at it.

MARCUS
(pacing)
We can’t panic. That’s what they want.

OLIVIA
(raising her voice)
I am not panicking! I am terrified. There’s a difference.

MARCUS
(quietly)
I know.

He sits beside her, hands clasped together. Silence stretches between them.

OLIVIA
(voice cracking)
What if we just… gave them what they want?

MARCUS
No.

OLIVIA
Why not? What are we protecting? Ourselves? Each other? Some ideal that died years ago?

MARCUS
We’re protecting the truth.

OLIVIA
(scoffing)
The truth? Whose truth? Ours? Theirs? The world’s?

MARCUS
Ours.

OLIVIA
And what about the world, Marcus? What about everyone else who gets caught in the crossfire?

MARCUS
We didn’t start this.

OLIVIA
But we’re in it. Up to our necks.

She stands abruptly, pacing the small space.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
Do you remember the first time we met?

MARCUS
Of course I do.

OLIVIA
You wore that ridiculous tweed jacket. The one with the elbow patches.

MARCUS
(smiling, despite himself)
You said I looked like a professor from a bad detective novel.

OLIVIA
(softening)
You did.

A beat.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
And I thought, “Here is a man who has never lied in his life.”

MARCUS
You were wrong.

OLIVIA
Were you?

MARCUS
I’ve lied to everyone, Olivia. Including you.

He looks away, ashamed.

OLIVIA
(quietly)
I know.

MARCUS
I’m sorry.

OLIVIA
I’m not asking for apologies. I’m asking for a plan.

MARCUS
We wait. We see if they make another move.

OLIVIA
And if they do?

MARCUS
Then we go to the police.

OLIVIA
You think the police can help us?

MARCUS
They have to.

OLIVIA
(voice rising)
Marcus, these people have been two steps ahead of us from the beginning. They know our addresses, our friends, our families. You think the police are going to protect us from that?

MARCUS
What do you want me to say?

OLIVIA
(suddenly exhausted)
I don’t know.

She sits, burying her face in her hands.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
I just want it to stop.

MARCUS
(softly)
Me too.

A long silence.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
We could run.

OLIVIA
(lifting her head)
Run where?

MARCUS
Anywhere. Disappear. New names, new lives.

OLIVIA
And leave everything behind?

MARCUS
If it means staying alive—

OLIVIA
(interrupting)
Alive, but not living.

MARCUS
Is this living?

She doesn’t answer.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
We made mistakes. But we’re not criminals.

OLIVIA
Aren’t we?

MARCUS
Not in any way that matters.

OLIVIA
Tell that to them.

She gestures at the letters again.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
They think we’re monsters.

MARCUS
They’re wrong.

OLIVIA
Are they? When I close my eyes, Marcus, all I see are the faces of the people we couldn’t save.

MARCUS
You did your best.

OLIVIA
My best wasn’t enough.

MARCUS
It has to be.

He reaches for her hand. She lets him take it, but her fingers are cold, limp.

OLIVIA
What if they come tonight?

MARCUS
They won’t.

OLIVIA
How do you know?

MARCUS
I just do.

OLIVIA
That’s not good enough.

MARCUS
It’s all I have.

She pulls her hand away, standing again. She moves to the window, peering through the rain.

OLIVIA
I hate this.

MARCUS
So do I.

OLIVIA
Do you think they’re watching us now?

MARCUS
Maybe.

OLIVIA
(voice trembling)
I feel like I can’t breathe.

MARCUS
Come here.

She hesitates, then lets him embrace her. He holds her tightly, as if he can shield her from the world.

OLIVIA
I wish I could just go back. Before any of this happened.

MARCUS
So do I.

A beat.

OLIVIA
Do you remember the night we found the ledger?

MARCUS
How could I forget?

OLIVIA
I thought it was a joke. Some elaborate prank.

MARCUS
So did I.

OLIVIA
But then I saw your face.

MARCUS
And you believed it was real.

OLIVIA
I didn’t want to.

MARCUS
Neither did I.

OLIVIA
If we’d just left it alone—

MARCUS
Then someone else would have found it.

OLIVIA
Maybe they would have known what to do.

MARCUS
Maybe they would have gotten themselves killed.

He lets go of her, moving to the table. He picks up another letter, reading silently.

OLIVIA
Do you ever regret it?

MARCUS
Every day.

He looks up, eyes meeting hers.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
But I’d do it again.

OLIVIA
Why?

MARCUS
Because someone had to.

OLIVIA
Did they?

MARCUS
Yes.

He sets the letter down, voice firm.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
They can threaten us. They can scare us. But they can’t make us forget what we saw.

OLIVIA
No. They can’t.

A beat.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
What about the others?

MARCUS
What do you mean?

OLIVIA
The people who helped us. The ones who know.

MARCUS
They’re safe.

OLIVIA
Are you sure?

MARCUS
I… I don’t know.

OLIVIA
We should warn them.

MARCUS
If we reach out, it could make things worse.

OLIVIA
And if we don’t?

MARCUS
We’re damned either way.

He sits heavily.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
We wait. Just a little longer.

OLIVIA
I’m so tired, Marcus.

MARCUS
Get some rest. I’ll keep watch.

OLIVIA
You promise?

MARCUS
I promise.

She nods, curling up on the couch, clutching a pillow. Marcus watches her, worry etched deep into his face.

The rain intensifies, rattling the windowpane.

CUT TO:

#part 2

EXT. CITY STREET – NIGHT

The rain pours down in sheets, washing the city in shimmering reflections. Marcus, umbrella clutched tightly, strides quickly down the deserted sidewalk, glancing over his shoulder at every shadow. The streetlights flicker, illuminating slick pavement and overflowing gutters.

A black sedan idles at the corner, engine humming. Marcus freezes, heart pounding, as the tinted window rolls down. A faceless silhouette inside raises a gloved hand, beckoning. Marcus hesitates, then bolts across the street. Tires squeal, headlights swinging to follow. He ducks into an alley, breath ragged, splashing through puddles.

Garbage cans topple as he scrambles over them, desperate. The sedan roars past the alley mouth, missing him by seconds. Marcus presses himself against the damp brick wall, chest heaving, listening as the car’s engine fades into the distance. He wipes rain from his face, checks his phone—no signal.

Lightning flashes, illuminating his pale, determined face. Sirens wail somewhere far off, echoing through the night. Marcus steels himself, slips deeper into the labyrinth of alleys, vanishing into the storm.

#part 3

INT. DIMLY LIT LIVING ROOM – LATER THAT NIGHT

The clock now reads 1:43 AM. Olivia sits at the table, a cold cup of tea untouched before her. The rain has eased, but thunder still rumbles in the distance. The room feels smaller now, as if the walls themselves are closing in.

The front door opens with a soft click. Olivia starts, her body tense. Marcus enters, soaked to the bone, hair plastered to his forehead. He locks the door behind him, double-checking the deadbolt.

OLIVIA
(standing, voice trembling)
Where were you?

MARCUS
(catching his breath)
I had to make sure. They were out there.

OLIVIA
Who?

MARCUS
The car. The same one from the other night. They followed me.

OLIVIA
You shouldn’t have gone out.

MARCUS
I had to know if they were watching.

He peels off his jacket, water pooling at his feet.

OLIVIA
And now they know you saw them.

MARCUS
They already knew.

Olivia crosses the room, wraps her arms around herself.

OLIVIA
What do we do now?

Marcus sits at the table, his hands shaking as he pours himself a cup of tea. He tries to steady himself, but the cup rattles against the saucer.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
Marcus.

He looks up, eyes haunted.

MARCUS
We can’t stay here.

OLIVIA
Where would we go?

MARCUS
Anywhere but here.

OLIVIA
We can’t just run forever.

MARCUS
If we don’t, we won’t last another night.

Olivia’s face crumples, but she forces herself to stay calm.

OLIVIA
Do you remember what you said to me the night before we published the first story?

MARCUS
You mean about being brave?

OLIVIA
You said, “Courage is just fear that’s said its prayers.”

MARCUS
I was trying to sound wise.

OLIVIA
It worked.

She sits across from him, her hands folded.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
I’m scared, Marcus. I’ve never been this scared.

MARCUS
Me too.

He takes her hands, squeezing gently.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
But I won’t let anything happen to you.

OLIVIA
You can’t promise that.

MARCUS
I can try.

They hold each other’s gaze, the silence charged.

OLIVIA
What if we called Sarah?

MARCUS
No. She’s out. She made that clear.

OLIVIA
But she has contacts. She could help us get out of the city.

MARCUS
She’s not going to risk her family for us.

OLIVIA
She wouldn’t have to know everything.

MARCUS
It’s too dangerous.

Olivia sighs, withdrawing her hands.

OLIVIA
We can’t do this alone.

Marcus looks away, jaw clenched.

MARCUS
We don’t have a choice.

OLIVIA
There’s always a choice.

MARCUS
Not for people like us.

She stands, moving to the window.

OLIVIA
You keep saying that, but it’s not true. We chose this. We chose to dig, to ask questions, to pull at threads everyone else ignored.

MARCUS
And look where it got us.

OLIVIA
Would you change it? If you could?

Marcus doesn’t answer.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
I would.

She turns, tears in her eyes.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
I would’ve stayed home that night. I would’ve let someone else chase the story.

MARCUS
You don’t mean that.

OLIVIA
Don’t I?

She wipes her eyes, angry at herself for crying.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
I miss my old life. I miss sleeping through the night. I miss not checking over my shoulder every time I leave the house.

MARCUS
I know.

He stands, approaches her.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
But if you hadn’t come with me, I never would’ve found the truth.

OLIVIA
And now the truth is going to get us killed.

Marcus puts a hand on her shoulder.

MARCUS
Not if we’re smart.

OLIVIA
We’ve been smart. We’ve been careful. It hasn’t stopped them.

MARCUS
We still have the files.

Olivia’s eyes widen.

OLIVIA
You didn’t destroy them?

MARCUS
I couldn’t. I made copies. Hid them.

OLIVIA
Where?

MARCUS
Somewhere safe.

OLIVIA
No place is safe.

MARCUS
This one is.

Olivia studies him.

OLIVIA
You trust someone?

MARCUS
I had to.

OLIVIA
Who?

MARCUS
You don’t want to know.

OLIVIA
Yes, I do.

Marcus hesitates, then shakes his head.

MARCUS
If they get to me, you’ll be safer not knowing.

OLIVIA
Don’t do that. Don’t shut me out.

MARCUS
I’m trying to protect you.

OLIVIA
Stop trying to protect me and start trusting me.

Marcus looks at her, really looks at her.

MARCUS
Alright.

He sits, exhausted.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
I gave them to David.

Olivia’s mouth falls open.

OLIVIA
David? David from the archive?

MARCUS
He owed me a favor. He’s clean, Olivia. No one knows about him.

OLIVIA
You’re sure?

MARCUS
As sure as I can be.

Olivia runs a hand through her hair.

OLIVIA
So what now?

MARCUS
We get out of the city. Lay low. Wait for David to contact us.

OLIVIA
And if he doesn’t?

Marcus hesitates.

MARCUS
Then we’re on our own.

Olivia sits, head in her hands.

OLIVIA
I can’t believe this is happening.

Marcus kneels beside her.

MARCUS
We’ll get through this.

She laughs, bitter.

OLIVIA
You always say that.

MARCUS
Because it’s true.

OLIVIA
It hasn’t been true for a long time.

She looks at him, defeated.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
I’m sorry, Marcus.

MARCUS
For what?

OLIVIA
For dragging you into this.

MARCUS
You didn’t drag me. I walked in with my eyes open.

Olivia wipes her eyes.

OLIVIA
I wish I was as brave as you.

MARCUS
You’re braver.

She shakes her head.

OLIVIA
No. I’m just stubborn.

MARCUS
That’s what makes you brave.

He smiles, trying to lighten the mood.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
Remember when you told off the editor at the Tribune?

Olivia laughs despite herself.

OLIVIA
He deserved it.

MARCUS
He did.

A brief silence.

OLIVIA
Do you think we’ll ever be able to go back?

MARCUS
To what?

OLIVIA
To normal.

Marcus considers.

MARCUS
I don’t know.

Olivia nods, accepting.

OLIVIA
I guess we should pack.

Marcus stands, stretching.

MARCUS
I’ll get the bags.

He crosses to the bedroom. Olivia starts gathering papers, moving with mechanical efficiency.

The phone rings, shrill in the quiet.

Olivia freezes.

OLIVIA (CONT’D)
Marcus?

He rushes back in.

MARCUS
Don’t answer it.

The phone rings again.

OLIVIA
What if it’s David?

MARCUS
He wouldn’t call here.

The phone falls silent. They exchange a look.

OLIVIA
Maybe it’s nothing.

MARCUS
Maybe.

He peers through the blinds. Nothing but darkness and rain.

Olivia resumes packing, her hands moving faster now.

OLIVIA
Do you think they’ll come tonight?

MARCUS
I don’t know.

OLIVIA
If they do, what will you do?

MARCUS
Whatever I have to.

She nods.

OLIVIA
You should change. You’re soaking wet.

MARCUS
Right.

He disappears into the bedroom. Olivia stands alone, staring at the door.

She whispers to herself.

OLIVIA
Please, just let us make it through the night.

Marcus returns, now in dry clothes, carrying two duffel bags.

MARCUS
Ready?

Olivia nods, taking one of the bags.

They move to the door. Marcus pauses, hand on the knob.

MARCUS (CONT’D)
No matter what happens, I want you to know—meeting you was the best thing that ever happened to me.

Olivia’s eyes fill with tears.

OLIVIA
Don’t say goodbye.

MARCUS
I’m not.

He opens the door. They slip out into the night, leaving the apartment dark and silent behind them.

FADE OUT.

##prompt_id: 6, type: segmented, sample_id: 2

#part 1

INT. LIVING ROOM – NIGHT

A spacious but cluttered living room, lit by a single, warm lamp. Old books are stacked haphazardly, and a chessboard sits mid-game on a coffee table. 

JULIA (40s), sharp-eyed, paces restlessly. Her brother, DAVID (mid-30s), sits on a faded couch, flicking through a worn notepad. Their mother, MRS. HARTLEY (late 60s), knits quietly in an armchair, her eyes darting between her children.

Julia stops pacing, arms folded.

JULIA
I can’t believe you’re still scribbling in that thing, David. You’re not going to find answers in a notebook.

DAVID
(softly)
It helps me think, Julia.

He puts the pen down, glances at Mrs. Hartley.

DAVID (CONT’D)
Did you hear from Dr. Kessler today, Mom?

MRS. HARTLEY
(sternly)
I did. He said he’d call with the test results. He hasn’t.

Julia sighs, moves to the window, peers out at the street below.

JULIA
It’s nearly midnight. They don’t call this late unless it’s—

DAVID
(interrupting)
Unless it’s important. Or bad news.

Silence. The only sound is the clicking of Mrs. Hartley’s knitting needles.

MRS. HARTLEY
We agreed not to jump to conclusions. Worrying doesn’t change anything.

Julia turns, her face tense.

JULIA
I’m not worrying. I’m being realistic.

DAVID
(sarcastic)
That’s your specialty.

Julia shoots him a glare.

JULIA
And what’s yours? Writing lists? Pretending everything’s fine?

DAVID
(quietly)
I’m trying to help.

MRS. HARTLEY
Enough. Both of you. This isn’t helping.

She sets her knitting aside, rubbing her temples.

MRS. HARTLEY (CONT’D)
I want peace tonight. Just for one evening.

Julia softens, walks over, crouches beside her mother.

JULIA
I’m sorry, Mom. I just… I can’t stand waiting.

Mrs. Hartley pats Julia’s cheek.

MRS. HARTLEY
You’ve always been impatient. Even as a child.

Julia laughs, a little choked.

JULIA
Well, you always said I was stubborn.

DAVID
(smiling)
She got that from you, Mom.

Mrs. Hartley gives David a look—part exasperated, part fond.

MRS. HARTLEY
Maybe. But I never let it turn me bitter.

Julia stands, paces again. David watches her, then looks at Mrs. Hartley.

DAVID
If the results are positive… we’ll figure it out. Together.

Julia scoffs.

JULIA
We don’t even know what we’re fighting yet.

DAVID
That’s why we wait.

A beat.

Julia stops at the chessboard, studies the pieces.

JULIA
Whose move is it?

DAVID
Yours, I think.

Julia picks up a knight, hesitates.

JULIA
I never liked this game. Too many possibilities.

DAVID
That’s what makes it interesting.

Julia moves her knight, sets it down with a thunk.

JULIA
I prefer certainty.

Mrs. Hartley chuckles, shaking her head.

MRS. HARTLEY
Life doesn’t give us certainty, darling. Only choices.

The phone rings, slicing through the tension. All three freeze.

JULIA
(whispering)
That’s him.

David stands, but Julia beats him to the phone.

JULIA (CONT’D)
(voice trembling)
Hello?

She listens, her face draining of color.

JULIA (CONT’D)
Yes, this is Julia Hartley. Yes, we’re all here.

She listens, nods, eyes wide.

JULIA (CONT’D)
I understand. Thank you.

She hangs up, silent.

DAVID
Julia?

Julia looks at her mother, then at David.

JULIA
It’s… it’s not cancer. They found something, but it’s not malignant.

Mrs. Hartley exhales, slumping back.

MRS. HARTLEY
Thank God.

David lets out a breath, moves to hug his mother.

DAVID
See? Not all waiting brings bad news.

Julia sits heavily on the couch, face in her hands.

JULIA
But he said there’s more tests. Biopsies. They don’t know what it is yet.

DAVID
One step at a time, Julia.

MRS. HARTLEY
He’s right. We take this as good news, for now.

Julia looks up, eyes shining.

JULIA
I’m sorry I snapped. I just… I couldn’t bear the thought of losing you, Mom.

Mrs. Hartley reaches across, squeezes Julia’s hand.

MRS. HARTLEY
You’re not losing me. Not yet.

The room is quiet, the tension eased but not gone.

David sits back, picks up the notepad.

DAVID
Maybe we should make a list, Julia. Things we can do while we wait.

Julia snorts, but smiles.

JULIA
Like what?

DAVID
Remember that jigsaw puzzle Mom’s been hiding in the closet for years?

Mrs. Hartley laughs.

MRS. HARTLEY
It’s missing half the sky. You’d never finish it.

Julia shrugs.

JULIA
Maybe that’s the point. Something to do, not something to finish.

David grins.

DAVID
I’ll get it.

He stands, heads to the hallway. Julia looks at her mother.

JULIA
Are you really okay?

MRS. HARTLEY
I’m tired. But I’m glad you’re both here.

Julia leans in, resting her head on her mother’s shoulder.

JULIA
We won’t let you go through this alone. Whatever it is.

Mrs. Hartley strokes Julia’s hair.

MRS. HARTLEY
I know, darling. I know.

David returns, a battered puzzle box in hand.

DAVID
Ready for a challenge?

Julia wipes her eyes, nods.

JULIA
Bring it on.

He dumps the pieces onto the table. They begin to sort through them, laughter mingling with sighs.

MRS. HARTLEY
You’ll never find all the edges.

DAVID
We’ll make do.

Julia holds up a blue piece, squints at it.

JULIA
Is this sky or water?

DAVID
Both, probably.

They fall into companionable silence, the worst fears pushed aside for now.

A clock ticks. The night deepens.

#part 2

EXT. CITY STREET – NIGHT

David steps out into the cool air, his breath visible in the glow of the streetlights. He shoves his hands in his pockets, shoulders hunched against the chill. The city is quiet, save for the distant hum of traffic.

He walks briskly, passing shuttered shops and the occasional stray cat. His phone buzzes—he glances at it, frowns, then ignores the call. At the intersection, he pauses, glancing up at the empty windows above. He exhales, tension evident in every line of his body.

A sudden shout echoes from a nearby alley. David freezes, then hurries toward the sound. He rounds the corner to see a TEENAGER, cornered by two older men. Without thinking, David shouts.

DAVID
Hey! Leave him alone!

The men hesitate; one sneers, but David steps closer, fists clenched.

DAVID (CONT’D)
I said back off!

The men exchange glances, then retreat into the shadows. The teenager bolts past David, disappearing down the street.

David stands alone, heart pounding, watching the darkness. He sucks in a shaky breath, and, after a moment, continues walking, his pace slower now, lost in thought.

#part 3

INT. LIVING ROOM – LATER THAT NIGHT

The puzzle remains half-finished on the table. Julia sits cross-legged on the floor, sorting through pieces. Mrs. Hartley has dozed off in her chair, knitting fallen to the floor. The lamp casts long shadows.

David enters quietly, closing the door behind him. He hesitates, watching his mother sleep, then sits beside Julia.

JULIA
You were gone a while.

DAVID
(sighs)
Needed some air.

Julia studies him, concern etched on her face.

JULIA
You okay?

DAVID
Yeah. Just… a lot on my mind.

Julia pushes a puzzle piece toward him.

JULIA
Help me with this? I can’t find the stupid corner.

David takes the piece, tries it in several places.

DAVID
You always hated puzzles.

JULIA
I hate not knowing where things fit.

She glances at their mother, voice softening.

JULIA (CONT’D)
I keep thinking about when Dad got sick. How lost I felt.

David nods, fitting a piece into place.

DAVID
I remember. You stopped talking to me for weeks.

JULIA
I was angry. At everyone. At you, at Mom, at him.

DAVID
At yourself?

Julia looks away.

JULIA
Maybe. I thought if I pretended it wasn’t happening, it would go away.

DAVID
It doesn’t work like that.

JULIA
I know.

A beat. Julia picks up another piece, turns it over in her hands.

JULIA (CONT’D)
Did you ever forgive him?

DAVID
For what?

JULIA
For leaving us.

DAVID
He didn’t choose to go, Julia.

JULIA
But he didn’t fight, either. Not like Mom.

David sets down his piece, looks at her.

DAVID
He fought in his own way. You just couldn’t see it.

Julia blinks back tears.

JULIA
I was so angry at him. And now I’m angry at her, too. For being sick. For making us go through this again.

DAVID
It’s not her fault.

JULIA
I know that. But it doesn’t change how I feel.

David puts an arm around her shoulders.

DAVID
You don’t have to be strong all the time, Julia.

JULIA
Someone does.

DAVID
Why? Who told you that?

Julia shrugs.

JULIA
Someone has to hold it together.

DAVID
We can hold it together. Both of us. Together.

Julia leans into him, silent for a moment.

JULIA
You always say the right thing.

DAVID
I don’t feel like I do.

JULIA
You do. Even when I don’t want to hear it.

They sit in silence, the only sound the ticking clock.

JULIA (CONT’D)
Where did you go, really?

DAVID
Just walked. Needed to clear my head.

Julia studies him.

JULIA
Something happened.

DAVID
(shrugs)
Not really. Just… ran into some trouble. It’s nothing.

JULIA
David.

DAVID
I’m fine. Just reminded me—life’s unpredictable.

Julia laughs, bitter.

JULIA
That’s an understatement.

DAVID
We can’t control what happens. Only how we react.

Julia sighs.

JULIA
I wish I could stop feeling so helpless.

DAVID
Maybe that’s part of it. Accepting that we can’t fix everything.

Julia looks at her mother, sleeping peacefully.

JULIA
She looks so small.

DAVID
She’s tougher than she looks.

JULIA
So were you, tonight. Whatever happened.

David smiles, shakes his head.

DAVID
I just did what I had to.

Julia squeezes his hand.

JULIA
Thank you.

He nods, eyes distant.

DAVID
Do you ever think about leaving? Just… running away from all this?

Julia considers.

JULIA
Sometimes. But I always come back.

DAVID
Me too.

Julia smiles, sad.

JULIA
We’re stuck with each other, aren’t we?

DAVID
Seems that way.

Julia glances at the puzzle.

JULIA
I found the corner.

She fits it into place. David grins.

DAVID
See? Progress.

Julia laughs, wiping her eyes.

JULIA
One piece at a time.

Mrs. Hartley stirs, blinking awake.

MRS. HARTLEY
Did I miss anything?

Julia moves to her mother’s side.

JULIA
Just the two of us being sentimental.

Mrs. Hartley smiles, reaching for their hands.

MRS. HARTLEY
I’m glad you have each other.

David squeezes her hand.

DAVID
We’re glad we have you.

Mrs. Hartley looks at Julia.

MRS. HARTLEY
When your father died, I thought I’d never survive it. But I did. Because of you two.

Julia blinks back tears.

JULIA
We weren’t exactly easy.

MRS. HARTLEY
No, but you loved me. That was enough.

David nods.

DAVID
It still is.

Mrs. Hartley sighs, content.

MRS. HARTLEY
Whatever happens, I want you to promise me something.

Julia leans in.

JULIA
Anything.

MRS. HARTLEY
Take care of each other. No matter what.

David and Julia exchange a look.

DAVID
We promise.

Mrs. Hartley settles back, closing her eyes.

MRS. HARTLEY
Good. That’s all I need.

Julia brushes a stray hair from her mother’s forehead.

JULIA
We’re not going anywhere.

Mrs. Hartley drifts back to sleep. Julia sits back, exhaling.

JULIA (CONT’D)
I’m scared, David.

DAVID
Me too.

Julia looks at him, vulnerable.

JULIA
What if it’s bad? What if she—

She can’t finish.

DAVID
Then we’ll face it. Together.

Julia nods, silent tears streaming down her face.

DAVID (CONT’D)
Remember when we were kids? You used to chase me around the garden with that rubber snake.

Julia laughs through her tears.

JULIA
You screamed so loud, the neighbors called Mom.

DAVID
You always protected me, Julia. Even when I didn’t want you to.

Julia wipes her eyes.

JULIA
I’d do it again.

DAVID
I know.

He hugs her. She clings to him.

JULIA
Promise me you won’t shut me out, if it gets hard.

DAVID
I promise. If you promise not to try to handle it all alone.

Julia nods.

JULIA
Deal.

They break apart, smiling.

Julia stands, stretches.

JULIA (CONT’D)
I’m making tea. Want some?

DAVID
Please.

Julia heads to the kitchen. David sits, watching his mother sleep.

A moment later, Julia returns with two mugs, hands one to David.

JULIA
Chamomile. Mom’s favorite.

DAVID
She’ll be happy when she wakes up.

Julia sits, sipping her tea.

JULIA (CONT’D)
Do you think she’s scared?

DAVID
Of course. But she won’t show it.

Julia nods.

JULIA
I wish I was more like her.

DAVID
You are. More than you think.

Julia smiles, grateful.

JULIA
Thank you.

They sip their tea in silence.

JULIA (CONT’D)
You know, I always thought I’d be the one to leave first. Move away, start over.

DAVID
What stopped you?

Julia shrugs.

JULIA
You. Mom. This place.

She looks around the room, at the old photos on the wall.

JULIA (CONT’D)
It’s not much, but it’s home.

DAVID
It’s everything.

Julia leans her head on his shoulder.

JULIA
Promise me, no matter what happens, we’ll remember this. This night. The three of us.

DAVID
I promise.

They sit, close, as the night deepens. The puzzle remains unfinished, but the edges are coming together.

FADE OUT.

#part 1

INT. OLD APARTMENT LIVING ROOM – NIGHT

A single, yellow bulb casts a tired light across the cluttered space. Boxes, faded books, and half-packed suitcases litter the floor. Rain spatters against the window. 

At the center, JUNE (early 30s, sharp, anxious) sits on a battered couch, knees drawn to her chest. Across from her, MARCO (late 30s, worn but warm) leans forward, elbows on his knees, hands clasped. The air between them is dense.

June clutches a faded photograph, her thumb rubbing the edge.

                                JUNE
            I found this in the kitchen drawer. Behind the old phone bills.

She holds up the photo—a younger Marco, smiling, arm slung around a woman neither June nor the audience recognizes.

                                MARCO
            (softly)
            You went through my things.

                                JUNE
            I was packing. It just… fell out.

                                MARCO
            (sighs)
            That’s Anna.

                                JUNE
            I figured. You never talked about her. About before.

Marco shifts, restless. He stares at the photo, then away.

                                MARCO
            Some things are easier that way.

June studies him, searching for a crack in the wall he’s built.

                                JUNE
            I’m not a stranger, Marco.

                                MARCO
            Didn’t say you were.

                                JUNE
            Then why do you treat me like one?

A tense silence. The rain intensifies.

                                MARCO
            You want to know about Anna? Fine. She was my wife. She left. End of story.

                                JUNE
            (quietly)
            Not end of story. Not for you.

                                MARCO
            June, we’re supposed to be leaving in the morning. What does this change?

                                JUNE
            Everything. Or nothing. Depends on what you say next.

Marco rubs his face. He looks tired, older.

                                MARCO
            All right. Ask.

June hesitates, then sets the photo on the coffee table.

                                JUNE
            Why did she leave?

Marco’s jaw tightens. He considers lying, but thinks better of it.

                                MARCO
            Because I couldn’t let go. Of what happened before her.

                                JUNE
            Before her?

                                MARCO
            My brother. The accident. I blamed myself. Still do, I guess.

June’s voice softens.

                                JUNE
            You never told me you had a brother.

                                MARCO
            He died when I was twenty. Drunk driver. I was supposed to pick him up, but I was late. Anna tried to help me move past it. I wouldn’t let her.

                                JUNE
            That’s not your fault.

                                MARCO
            Doesn’t matter. I made it mine.

June leans forward, her voice trembling.

                                JUNE
            Why are you telling me now?

                                MARCO
            Because you asked. Because maybe I’m tired of carrying it all by myself.

                                JUNE
            I’m here, Marco. I always was.

Marco looks at her, searching for trust, forgiveness.

                                MARCO
            I know. I just… I never wanted to drag you into my mess.

June stands, pacing, her own tension rising.

                                JUNE
            We’re moving across the country together. If that’s not “in your mess,” I don’t know what is.

                                MARCO
            (cracks a smile)
            Guess you’re right.

June stops, facing him.

                                JUNE
            Do you still talk to her? Anna?

                                MARCO
            No. Haven’t in years. She’s remarried, I think. Has a kid.

                                JUNE
            Do you regret it? Losing her?

Marco is silent a long time.

                                MARCO
            I regret not letting her in. Not trusting her with the truth.

                                JUNE
            And me? Are you going to trust me?

Marco’s eyes are glassy. He nods, barely.

                                MARCO
            I want to.

June sits beside him. Their hands find each other, tentative.

                                JUNE
            We can’t build something new if you’re still living in the old.

                                MARCO
            I know.

A long silence. The clock ticks. June squeezes his hand.

                                JUNE
            Tomorrow. We start over.

                                MARCO
            Tomorrow.

She leans her head on his shoulder. The rain slows. Marco closes his eyes, breathing her in.

                                JUNE
            There’s more, isn’t there?

                                MARCO
            (after a beat)
            There’s always more.

                                JUNE
            I can take it.

Marco pulls away slightly, searching her face.

                                MARCO
            Are you sure?

                                JUNE
            I’m still here.

He stands, crossing to a battered desk. He opens a drawer, retrieving a small, velvet box. He hesitates, then hands it to her.

                                MARCO (CONT’D)
            I was going to ask you after we got settled. But maybe now’s better.

June opens the box—a silver ring, simple, elegant.

                                JUNE
            Marco…

                                MARCO
            I know I’m not perfect. I know I have baggage. But I want to try. With you.

June’s eyes fill with tears. She laughs, shaky.

                                JUNE
            You idiot. You didn’t have to wait.

                                MARCO
            Maybe I did. Maybe I needed to know you’d stay, even after you saw the worst parts.

                                JUNE
            I saw them a long time ago. I stayed.

She slips the ring on her finger. It fits.

                                JUNE (CONT’D)
            So, what now? We just… go?

                                MARCO
            We go. Together.

They hold each other. The room, for the first time, feels lighter.

                                JUNE
            What about your brother? Do you ever visit him?

Marco shakes his head.

                                MARCO
            I haven’t been back since the funeral.

                                JUNE
            Maybe we should. Before we leave.

                                MARCO
            You’d do that?

                                JUNE
            For you? For us.

Marco nods, overwhelmed.

                                MARCO
            Thank you.

June brushes a tear from his cheek.

                                JUNE
            Thank you for letting me in.

They sit together, the silence now peaceful. June looks at the photo of Anna, then at Marco.

                                JUNE (CONT’D)
            Do you think she’s happy?

                                MARCO
            I hope so.

                                JUNE
            You deserve to be, too.

                                MARCO
            Maybe this is how.

They sit, entwined, as the rain fades into quiet.

#part 2

EXT. CEMETERY – DAY

Gray clouds drift above a sprawling cemetery. June and Marco walk side by side, bundled against the wind. Marco clutches a small bouquet of wildflowers; June holds his arm tightly.

They wind through the rows of headstones, Marco’s steps slow, deliberate. He stops before a modest grave—LUCA BIANCHI, beloved brother and son.

Marco kneels, placing the flowers gently. June stands behind, her hand on his shoulder.

Marco bows his head, lips moving in silent prayer. June joins him, kneeling. The wind stirs the grass. Marco traces the name on the stone, eyes brimming.

June squeezes his hand, anchoring him. Together, they rise. Marco lingers, then turns away, a weight lifted.

They walk back toward the car, closer than before.

#part 3

INT. OLD APARTMENT LIVING ROOM – EVENING

Sunset filters through thin curtains, painting the walls gold. The packed boxes now line the door. The apartment is emptier, the echo of their voices more pronounced.

June sits at the kitchen table, sorting through a stack of letters. Marco stands by the window, lost in thought, the cemetery visit still fresh in his mind.

                                JUNE
            I found another one.

Marco turns, wary.

                                MARCO
            Another what?

                                JUNE
            Letter. From your mother. Unopened.

Marco’s jaw tenses. He crosses to her, taking the envelope. The handwriting is familiar, looping.

                                MARCO
            She wrote after Luca died. I never answered.

June studies him, gentle.

                                JUNE
            Maybe you should read it.

He hesitates, then tears open the envelope. His hands tremble as he unfolds the paper.

                                MARCO
            (reading aloud, voice shaky)
            “My dear Marco, I know you’re hurting. I know you blame yourself, but I want you to remember, Luca loved you. He looked up to you. He wouldn’t want you to carry this pain. Come home when you’re ready. I’m always here. Love, Mama.”

He sets the letter down, eyes shining.

                                JUNE
            She sounds kind.

                                MARCO
            She was. I haven’t spoken to her in years.

                                JUNE
            Do you want to?

Marco sits, head in hands.

                                MARCO
            I don’t know. I’m not sure she’d want to hear from me.

June reaches across the table, taking his hand.

                                JUNE
            She said she’d always be there.

Marco nods, silent.

                                JUNE (CONT’D)
            You don’t have to decide now.

                                MARCO
            I know.

A beat.

                                JUNE
            I called my mother. Told her we’re moving.

Marco looks up, surprised.

                                MARCO
            How did she take it?

                                JUNE
            Better than I expected. She said I always did things my own way.

                                MARCO
            She’s not wrong.

June laughs, tension easing.

                                JUNE
            She wants to meet you.

                                MARCO
            That’s terrifying.

                                JUNE
            She’s not so bad. Just... opinionated.

Marco grins.

                                MARCO
            I can handle opinionated.

June sets aside the letters, looking at the empty room.

                                JUNE
            I’m going to miss this place.

                                MARCO
            Even the leaky faucet?

                                JUNE
            Especially the leaky faucet. It sang to me at night.

Marco shakes his head, smiling.

                                MARCO
            I can’t believe we’re really doing this.

                                JUNE
            Me neither.

A quiet falls. June fidgets with the ring on her finger.

                                JUNE (CONT’D)
            When did you decide?

                                MARCO
            About the ring? Months ago. I carried it everywhere, waiting for the right moment.

                                JUNE
            Was there ever a right moment?

                                MARCO
            Maybe not. Maybe you just make one.

June leans back, thoughtful.

                                JUNE
            I used to imagine what my life would look like, you know? When I was a kid.

                                MARCO
            And?

                                JUNE
            It never looked like this. But I think that’s a good thing.

Marco nods, understanding.

                                MARCO
            I never saw myself here either. Or with you. Not because I didn’t want to, just… didn’t think I deserved it.

                                JUNE
            You do.

                                MARCO
            I’m starting to believe you.

June stands, crossing to the window. She looks out at the city, the lights flickering on.

                                JUNE
            Do you think we’ll be happy there?

                                MARCO
            I don’t know. But I think we’ll have a chance.

                                JUNE
            That’s enough.

She turns, her face serious.

                                JUNE (CONT’D)
            Marco, if you ever feel like you’re slipping—like before—you have to tell me.

                                MARCO
            I will.

                                JUNE
            Promise?

                                MARCO
            I promise.

She studies him, searching for doubt, but finds only resolve.

                                JUNE
            Good.

She sits again, closer this time.

                                JUNE (CONT’D)
            What was he like? Your brother.

Marco smiles, bittersweet.

                                MARCO
            Wild. Funny. He always knew how to get me in trouble. But he was kind. He’d give you his last dollar if you needed it.

                                JUNE
            You miss him.

                                MARCO
            Every day.

                                JUNE
            I wish I’d met him.

                                MARCO
            He would’ve liked you. Probably would’ve warned you about me.

                                JUNE
            Would I have listened?

                                MARCO
            Probably not.

They share a quiet laugh.

                                JUNE
            I’m scared, Marco.

He looks at her, surprised.

                                MARCO
            Of what?

                                JUNE
            Of leaving. Of failing. Of losing myself in all this.

                                MARCO
            You won’t. I won’t let you.

                                JUNE
            You can’t promise that.

                                MARCO
            No. But I can promise I’ll be there, no matter what.

June’s eyes glisten.

                                JUNE
            I need you to be.

                                MARCO
            I need you, too.

She sighs, wiping her eyes.

                                JUNE
            God, listen to us. Two grown adults, terrified of starting over.

                                MARCO
            I think that’s normal.

                                JUNE
            Maybe. Or maybe we’re just cowards.

                                MARCO
            No. Cowards would stay. We’re going.

June laughs, the sound bright.

                                JUNE
            You’re right.

A knock at the door startles them. June stands, wary.

                                JUNE (CONT’D)
            Are you expecting someone?

                                MARCO
            No.

She opens the door. A NEIGHBOR, MRS. RILEY (60s, spry), stands holding a plate of cookies.

                                MRS. RILEY
            I heard you two were leaving. Thought you might need something sweet for the road.

June smiles, touched.

                                JUNE
            Thank you, Mrs. Riley. That’s so kind.

                                MRS. RILEY
            You take care of each other, you hear?

                                MARCO
            We will.

Mrs. Riley squeezes Marco’s arm, her eyes kind.

                                MRS. RILEY
            Don’t forget, you can always come back.

                                JUNE
            We won’t forget.

Mrs. Riley leaves. June closes the door, holding the plate.

                                JUNE
            People are going to miss us.

                                MARCO
            Or your baking.

                                JUNE
            My baking is terrible.

                                MARCO
            That’s why they’re giving us cookies.

They laugh, the tension easing.

                                JUNE
            Do you want to try calling your mother?

Marco looks at the phone, then at June.

                                MARCO
            I’m not ready. But soon.

                                JUNE
            I’ll be here when you are.

                                MARCO
            I know.

A long silence. June moves to the bookshelf, pulling out a battered novel.

                                JUNE
            Remember when you read this to me? That first winter?

                                MARCO
            You had the flu. I thought you’d never forgive me for my terrible accents.

                                JUNE
            I didn’t. But you kept reading.

                                MARCO
            You kept listening.

June hugs the book to her chest.

                                JUNE
            I want to remember everything. Even the hard parts.

                                MARCO
            Me too.

She sets the book in a box, marking it “KEEP.”

                                JUNE
            Do you think we’ll forget?

                                MARCO
            No. It’ll just… change shape.

                                JUNE
            I hope you’re right.

Marco stands, crossing to her. He takes her hands.

                                MARCO
            I am.

She smiles, tired but hopeful.

                                JUNE
            We should get some sleep. Early start.

                                MARCO
            I’ll finish the last of the packing.

                                JUNE
            Together.

They move through the apartment, boxing the last remnants of their life here—a chipped mug, a faded scarf, a photograph of the two of them at the beach.

As they work, they talk—about small things, big things, dreams for the future. The conversation weaves through laughter and tears, confessions and reassurances.

At last, the apartment is bare. June stands in the doorway, looking back.

                                JUNE (CONT’D)
            Ready?

Marco joins her, keys in hand.

                                MARCO
            As I’ll ever be.

She takes his hand. Together, they step into the hallway, closing the door on the past.

FADE OUT.

#part 1

INT. LIVING ROOM – EVENING

A modern, tastefully decorated living room. A muted, golden light filters in from tall windows. On the couch, EMMA (early 30s, sharp, anxious) sits, fidgeting with her phone. Across from her in a high-backed chair sits DAVID (mid-40s, composed, reserved), his posture formal. Between them, a coffee table with untouched mugs of tea.

A long silence. The clock ticks. Emma glances at David, then away.

EMMA  
(voice barely above a whisper)  
You’re not going to say anything?

DAVID  
(softly)  
I’m waiting for you to start.

Emma presses her lips together, fighting to keep her composure.

EMMA  
(starting and stopping)  
I— I just… I don’t know how to—  
(she sighs)  
I’m sorry. I know you hate that, but I am.

DAVID  
(his face unreadable)  
I don’t hate apologies, Emma. I hate when they’re meaningless.

Emma looks wounded. She picks up her mug, then sets it down untouched.

EMMA  
It isn’t meaningless. I mean it. I know what I did— I know it hurt you.

DAVID  
Which part? The lying, or the hiding?

EMMA  
Both.  
(she looks up, eyes wet)  
I should have told you. I should have trusted you.

DAVID  
Why didn’t you?

Emma opens her mouth, then closes it. She looks around the room, at the bookshelves, the lamp, anything but David.

EMMA  
I thought… I thought if you knew, you’d look at me differently. That you’d see me the way everyone else does.

DAVID  
And how is that?

EMMA  
(voice trembling)  
Like I’m broken. Weak. Like I can’t be trusted with anything important.

David’s expression softens, just a little.

DAVID  
Emma, I’ve never—  
(he stops himself)  
You know I don’t see you that way.

EMMA  
But you would have. If you’d known.

DAVID  
(slowly)  
If I’d known what? That you were struggling? That you made a mistake?

Emma shakes her head, frustrated.

EMMA  
It’s not just a mistake. It’s everything. The money, the accounts, the way I let it all spiral— I was in over my head and I kept pretending I wasn’t.

David leans forward, elbows on his knees.

DAVID  
You could have come to me. That’s what partners do.

EMMA  
I know!  
(her voice rises, then she lowers it, embarrassed)  
I know. But every time I tried, I just… froze. I kept thinking, “Not tonight. Tomorrow. Next week.” And then it was too late.

DAVID  
It’s not too late.

Emma finally looks at him, her eyes searching.

EMMA  
Isn’t it? I mean, after today— after what you found—

DAVID  
(quietly)  
I was angry. I still am. But I’m here, aren’t I?

Emma nods, wiping her eyes.

EMMA  
I wish I could go back.

DAVID  
We can’t.

He sits back, folding his arms.

DAVID (CONT’D)  
Let’s talk about the money.

Emma’s jaw clenches. She nods.

EMMA  
Okay.

DAVID  
How much?

EMMA  
(voice small)  
Twenty-three thousand. Maybe a little more.

David absorbs this, face tight.

DAVID  
How?

EMMA  
The business— the expenses kept coming, and the clients were late paying, and I thought if I just borrowed a little from the savings, I could pay it back when things picked up. But things never picked up.

DAVID  
So you kept borrowing.

EMMA  
Yes.

DAVID  
And the credit cards?

EMMA  
Maxed. I’m sorry.

David closes his eyes for a moment.

DAVID  
Did you tell your mother?

EMMA  
No. She’d panic. You know how she gets.

DAVID  
(voice rising)  
And you thought I wouldn’t?  
(he softens)  
Emma, I can handle panic. What I can’t handle is being shut out.

EMMA  
I know. I’m sorry.

DAVID  
Stop saying that unless you mean it.

EMMA  
I do mean it!  
(she leans forward, desperate)  
I know I messed up. I know you’re angry— you should be. But I need you, David. I can’t fix this by myself.

DAVID  
You should have said that months ago.

EMMA  
I know.

David takes a deep breath, steadying himself.

DAVID  
We’ll figure it out. But I need you to be honest, from now on. No more secrets.

EMMA  
(nodding)  
No more secrets.

A beat.

DAVID  
And the emails? The ones you deleted?

Emma hesitates.

EMMA  
I panicked. I thought if you saw the overdue notices, you’d… I don’t know, leave.

DAVID  
Leave?

EMMA  
Yes.

David looks at her, hurt.

DAVID  
Emma, I’m here. I’ve always been here.

EMMA  
I know.  
(she chokes back tears)  
I just… I didn’t want to lose you.

David stands, pacing, running his hands through his hair.

DAVID  
You never gave me the chance to help. You just… built this wall.

EMMA  
I know.

DAVID  
Why?

EMMA  
Because I’m scared, okay? I’m scared all the time. Of failing, of disappointing you, of not being enough.

DAVID  
You are enough.

EMMA  
(skeptical)  
Am I?

DAVID  
Yes.

A pause. Emma’s breathing slows.

EMMA  
What do we do now?

DAVID  
First, we figure out exactly how bad it is. All the accounts, all the debts. No more hiding.

EMMA  
Okay.

DAVID  
Then we make a plan. Together.

EMMA  
Okay.

DAVID  
And you have to promise me— if you’re scared, or overwhelmed, or if you mess up again, you tell me.

EMMA  
I promise.

David sits beside her, taking her hand.

DAVID  
We’ll get through this. But it has to be together.

Emma nods, tears streaming down her cheeks.

EMMA  
Thank you.

DAVID  
Don’t thank me yet.

They sit in silence, hands clasped, the weight of the conversation settling over them.

EMMA  
Do you hate me?

DAVID  
No.

EMMA  
Are you sure?

DAVID  
I’m angry, I’m hurt, I’m disappointed. But I don’t hate you.

Emma lets out a shaky breath.

EMMA  
I want to fix this.

DAVID  
So do I.

She squeezes his hand.

EMMA  
I wish I could make it disappear.

DAVID  
We can’t. But we can face it.

EMMA  
Okay.

Another silence. The clock ticks.

DAVID  
I’m going to need you to show me everything. All the accounts, the bills, the emails. Everything.

EMMA  
I will.

DAVID  
Tonight.

Emma nods, steeling herself.

EMMA  
Tonight.

DAVID  
And Emma?

EMMA  
Yeah?

DAVID  
No more lies.

EMMA  
No more lies.

They sit together, a fragile peace settling between them.

Suddenly, the sound of a key in the front door. Emma tenses.

DAVID  
Are you expecting someone?

EMMA  
No.

The door opens. JASON (late 20s, disheveled, urgent) bursts in, breathless.

JASON  
Emma! You have to come. Now.

Emma stands, alarmed.

EMMA  
Jason? What’s wrong?

JASON  
It’s Mom. She collapsed. The ambulance is outside.

Emma’s face drains of color. She grabs her coat.

EMMA  
(to David)  
I have to go.

DAVID  
I’m coming with you.

They rush out, leaving the mugs and the silence behind.

#part 2

EXT. SUBURBAN STREET – NIGHT

Blue and red ambulance lights flash across the quiet neighborhood. Emma, David, and Jason hurry down the front steps, their breath visible in the cold air. Paramedics wheel MRS. HART (mid-60s, frail) on a stretcher toward the open ambulance. Emma runs to her mother’s side, grabbing her hand.

EMMA  
Mom! Can you hear me?

Mrs. Hart’s eyes flutter, unfocused. A paramedic gently urges Emma back.

PARAMEDIC  
We need space, ma’am.

Jason stands frozen, fists clenched. David wraps an arm around his shoulders, steadying him. Emma backs away, tears streaming down her face as the paramedics load Mrs. Hart into the ambulance. The doors slam shut.

PARAMEDIC (CONT’D)  
We’re headed to Mercy General. Follow us there.

Emma nods frantically, stumbling toward her car. David takes the keys from her, guiding her into the passenger seat. Jason slides into the back, silent and pale.

As the ambulance speeds away, its siren wailing, Emma’s world narrows to the flashing lights vanishing into the night.

#part 3

INT. HOSPITAL WAITING ROOM – NIGHT

Harsh fluorescent lights. Emma, David, and Jason sit huddled on plastic chairs, all three pale and exhausted. The waiting room is nearly empty, save for an elderly couple whispering in the far corner. Emma stares at the floor, hands clenched in her lap.

JASON  
(voice barely audible)  
They said she was stable. That’s good, right?

DAVID  
(nods, reassuring)  
It’s good. They’re just running tests.

JASON  
I shouldn’t have left her alone tonight.

EMMA  
It’s not your fault.

JASON  
(staring at the floor)  
She sounded fine when I called. Just tired.

EMMA  
She’s been tired for weeks. I should have noticed.

JASON  
You have enough on your plate.

EMMA  
She’s our mother.

DAVID  
(softly)  
You’re both here now. That’s what matters.

DR. COLLINS  
Family of Margaret Hart?

They all stand.

EMMA  
That’s us.

Your mother is stable. We believe she had a minor stroke. She’s conscious, but disoriented. We’re admitting her for observation.

Relief floods Emma’s face.

EMMA  
Can we see her?

DR. COLLINS  
One at a time for now. She needs rest.

Emma nods, looking to Jason.

EMMA  
You go first.

Jason hesitates, then nods and follows Dr. Collins out. Emma sits again, body slumping.

DAVID  
(quietly)  
You okay?

EMMA  
No.

DAVID  
Come here.

He moves closer, putting an arm around her. She leans against him, shaking.

EMMA  
I can’t do this, David.

DAVID  
You’re doing it.

EMMA  
I let everything fall apart. The business, the money, Mom—

DAVID  
You’re not responsible for everything.

EMMA  
Aren’t I? I should have checked on her. I should have told you the truth. Maybe if I wasn’t so wrapped up in my own mess, I would’ve seen—

DAVID  
Emma.  
(he gently turns her to face him)  
You can’t carry this all by yourself.

EMMA  
I don’t know how to stop.

DAVID  
Let me help.

EMMA  
I’m scared.

DAVID  
Of what?

EMMA  
That it’s too late. That I’ve already ruined everything.

DAVID  
You haven’t.

How do you know?

Because I’m still here. Jason’s still here. Your mother’s alive.

EMMA  
I feel like I’m drowning.

Then hold on to me.

She nods, silent tears slipping down her cheeks. Jason returns, eyes red.

JASON  
She asked for you.

Emma stands, taking a deep breath.

EMMA  
Okay.

She leaves. David and Jason sit in awkward silence.

JASON  
I didn’t know things were so bad.

DAVID  
Neither did I.

JASON  
I knew about the business. She told me she was stressed, but not… not all this.

She’s asking now.

She’s lucky to have you.

We’re all lucky to have each other.

INT. HOSPITAL ROOM – NIGHT

Dim light. Mrs. Hart lies in bed, pale but awake. Emma enters quietly, forcing a smile.

EMMA  
Hi, Mom.

MRS. HART  
Emma.  
(her voice is weak, but warm)  
You look tired.

EMMA  
So do you.

MRS. HART  
Don’t fuss.

I’m not fussing.

You always fuss.

You scared us.

Did I?

Jason called. We came as soon as we heard.

Mrs. Hart looks at her, studying her face.

MRS. HART  
You’re worried.

EMMA  
Of course I’m worried.

MRS. HART  
About me, or everything else?

Emma blinks, caught off guard.

EMMA  
Both.

MRS. HART  
You never did tell me what’s wrong. Not really.

I didn’t want to worry you.

That’s not your job.

Thank God.

We take care of her. We figure out the rest— together.

I haven’t been honest. About the business. The money. I let things get out of control and I hid it from you.

How bad?

Pretty bad.

Why didn’t you tell me?

EMMA  
I was ashamed. I didn’t want you to see me fail.

EMMA  
I’m sorry.

JASON  
We’ll figure it out.  
(he looks at David)  
Right?

DAVID  
Right.

Emma exhales, the truth a weight lifted.

Thank you.

They sit together, a family— bruised, but not broken.
